Works on all other program except vscode.

title: allow `Git: fetch` command to show password prompt

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
There was some 2 years old code which was preventing `Git: fetch` command from displaying a password prompt. I've removed this special treatment. Tested, now `Git: fetch` is showing password prompt as expected and the operation is also successful.

Fixes #72613

title: Some GIT commands do not show password prompt

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
### Preconditions

* I'm working with a _password protected Git repo_ in VS Code
* I open _command pallet_ (F1) and execute a Git command

Now most commands like `pull`, `push`, etc. _correctly asks for a password_ by showing a UI password prompt.

### Issue

However, certain commands like `fetch`, etc. **do not ask for a password** by showing a UI password prompt and fails with error `Git: Missing or invalid credentials.`

title: Reading Mode Request
body: Issue Type: Feature Request This issue is about battery life on laptop. I used to regard vscode as a light-weight editor.And I found vscode is more powerful than I thought.So I got a lot of extensions and I ran programs on it. it's powerful. ***it's too powerful,sometimes*** what I'm saying is,while using vscode with a lot of extensions,CPU usage is much higher than other pure text editor. ***So,Maybe a pure reading view is good for people reading code with battery*** If you can turn on reading view,extensions for intellisense and some powerful functions will be disabled,leaving the highlighting only,becoming a primitive text editor VS Code version: Code 1.33.1 (51b0b28134d51361cf996d2f0a1c698247aeabd8, 2019-04-11T08:27:14.102Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

title: Git: Support aborting the current rebase

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
It's very common to have to resolve merge conflicts during a pull with rebase. You might decide that you want to *stop* and try something else. There's no way, that I found, through the source control UI or command palette to properly abort a rebase.

You can get into a jam trying to abort, though. Like clicking the branch button in the status bar. You can choose your local branch and have the local branch's contents restored, but Code leaves you in a rebase (and that's no good).

You're stuck running `git rebase --abort` on the command line.

(I'll upload some pics later when I can contrive some examples... sorry, I didn't capture them while I was causing trouble earlier.)

title: Debugger for Chrome: Doesn't work, when using NTLM and deny anonymous access
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
Version: 1.33.1 (user setup)
Commit: 51b0b28134d51361cf996d2f0a1c698247aeabd8
Date: 2019-04-11T08:27:14.102Z
Electron: 3.1.6
Chrome: 66.0.3359.181
Node.js: 10.2.0
V8: 6.6.346.32
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download and unzip the [project](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/3093084/VSCodeDebug.zip)
 (it's the default dotnet angular project setting).
2. Open it with VSCode and restore all packages.
3. Hit CTRL+ALT+F5 and start debugging the client (If not done yet, it will install all node modules, so this could take some time).
4. When the server is running hit CTRL+ALT+F5 again and start debugging the client.
5. In the ClientApp\src\app\home\home.component.ts is a little method where you can set a breakpoint
6. In the Browser on the starting page is a button which calls the onClick() method. Click the button. --> Despite the breakpoint for the onClick method nothing debug-related happens when you click the button.
7. Stop all running debuggers and switch to Program.cs
8. Remove or comment out the following line `options.Authentication.AllowAnonymous = false;`
9. Repeat Steps 3 - 5
10. When you now click the "Click me" button, the debugger for Chrome works as expected.

The debugger shipped with Chrome is working, even when the windows authentication is enabled and this should be the behavior for the "Debugger for Chrome" extension as well.

title: Support restart of remote EH to avoid window reloads

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
It looks like we added code to the workbench to reload the window in certain cases when entering a workspace or folders change:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/053a32e2bbc354af2b19cb40758f615cefcb714e/src/vs/workbench/services/workspace/electron-browser/workspaceEditingService.ts#L366

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/053a32e2bbc354af2b19cb40758f615cefcb714e/src/vs/workbench/contrib/relauncher/electron-browser/relauncher.contribution.ts#L163

There should only be very few reasons why this is needed (e.g. a global settings change) and in that case we tell the user at least and offer to cancel that.

Here we just reload without warning (which is quite horrible if e.g. the user has decided to disable hot-exit and then needs to deal with untitled/unsaved buffers).

title: index.js/index.ts file should show at top of file picker when searching for the name of the directory
body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.34.0-insider (1.34.0-insider) 6d5feae57959287fb116467f4eb6c7079571b466 - OS Version: MacOS 10.14.4 **Expected:** In TypeScript, index.js should show up at or near the top of the list, identically to if it was called `./MyComponent.ts`. (Since index.ts is a shorthand for "whatever this directory is" - e.g. `MyComponent/index.ts` can be imported as just `./MyComponent`). Note that there is currently no clean and quick way to open such a file since typing "index" is highly general and may bring up a huge list, and the dev doesn't know to type both the component name and index because it's not clear by looking at the import line that the module is being imported from a file named "index.ts". **Actual:** File often appears well down the list of choices, including below items that are seldom if ever selected. Example typing "regi" and wanting to open "registerLoginRoutes/index.ts": **Steps to Reproduce:** 1. Create an index.ts file within a directory 2. Cmd+p to open file search box 3. Start typing the name of the directory Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Goto Line: ^G n where n > # lines in file should result in navigation to last line
body:
**To Reproduce:**
- Open a text file with more than 10 lines and not more than 999998 lines
- use the goto Line feature `^G`
- type `999999` and then press `[Enter]`

**Current Results:**
- Cursor does not leave the input box until mouse is used or number is set to less than or equal to the number of lines and then `[Enter]` is pressed

**Desired Results:**
- Entering a number greater than the number of lines defaults to the last line in the file. (similar to vi's `#G`)

title: Proposal: Animate `workspace.applyEdit`
body:
Here's an idea I had for a small opt-in feature for extensions that use `workspace.applyEdit`.

VS Code Share already implements a system for "multiplayer" code editing, with colored cursors for each user:

![](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/liveshare/media/vscode-follow-multiple-viewlet.png)

If changes applied via `workspace.applyEdit` were animated with a similar cursor/highlight pattern, it would be possible to write more useful formatters that run between document saves.

Here's an example of the proposed workflow:

- User is working in a JavaScript file with a formatting rule enforcing semicolons.
- He or she writes a line of code without ending it in a semicolon.
- The user then moves the cursor to a different part of the document, more than 4 lines away.
- A colorful cursor labeled "ESLint" briefly appears, types the semicolon, then disappears.

The effect would also apply in similar scenarios:
- If a formatter were deleting a section of code, the cursor could highlight it first before removal.
- If the user applied a code action, they'd be able to see the effects of that code action as the cursor bounced through the document.
- There would likely need to be an upper limit to the size an edit is permitted to be, while still being animated by the system. Otherwise, large formatting changes would be overwhelming and possibly impact performance.

Such a workflow would have the following benefits:
- "Inexpensive" edits, such as adjusting whitespace or adding semicolons, could be applied immediately instead of waiting for the user to save the document. This would reduce the number of squiggly underlines, in turn making it easier for the user to scan their document for the errors and warnings which truly warrant their attention.
- Labeling the cursor with the formatter's name allows the user to understand why a particular edit was applied.
- Waiting for the cursor to move at least 4 lines away ensures that the user never "fights with" the formatter. Users would be able to configure this distance to their comfort.
- It would be fun to use and make the application feel more futuristic, almost as if the IDE were a peer instead of a tool 👨🤝🤖 

This effect could be faked on a case-by-case basis using decorations, but I think it would be incredible if this were implemented and widely used. This animation would be off by default, but extension authors would be able to opt in with a flag.

This is definitely similar to the "Format On Type" setting, and could be implemented as a refinement of that.

title: Add hover transparency
body:
Issue Type: Bug(-ish) Tooltips inside the code editor are really useful, but... Also go away! When I hover my mouse over something slowly enough in order to find that one spot I need to start typing, a tooltip may show up. I need to be somewhere along the lines I'm looking at. Now a tooltip is obscuring the code I was looking at. Still not a huge problem. Now I need to be one or two lines above the word where the tooltip showed up for. How do I make the tooltip go away? I click frantically, but in the process I just select the text in the tooltip? Why would I even want that? Go away! Shoo! By now, I forgot what I needed to do. Turns out, I need to move my mouse well away from where I need to be, in order to make the tooltip disappear. By then, my eyes are focused nowhere near where I needed to be in my code. I have to re-find that spot, carefully avoiding that tooltip that ripped my out of my flow earlier. This is not happening on a single instance. This happens many times a day. In conclusion: It must be easier to do away with the tooltip. I *don't* want it to bother me. I *do* want it to be useful to me. In retrospect: The story above, of course, happens nothing as slowly as I make it out to be. It happens in a second or so. But that second, every time, takes me out of my concentration. I think we all know how that feels. Proposed solutions: * Click the tooltip to make it dissappear. * Have it be "click-through" where clicks on it are actually clicks behind it. * Have it display away from the mouse cursor's trajectory. Display it above the cursor if moving downward, display below the cursor if moving upward. * Don't display the helptext as a tooltip at all, but in a fixed position somewhere. VS Code version: Code 1.33.0 (0dd516dd412d42323fc3464531b1c715d51c4c1a, 2019-04-04T15:14:28.026Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

title: OS X: extension contributed protocol handler not invoked when no window is open
body:
On OS X
- close all Windows but keep the vscode application running
- in chrome navigate to this URL `vscode://vscode.git/clone?url=https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode.git`
-> an empty window opens, but the protocol handler is not invoked.

Executing the same steps with a window open works and triggers the protocol handler.

title: Support serverReadyAction in tasks.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
`launch.json` added `serverReadyAction` which [automatically opens a browser tab based on a text match in the debug console or integrated terminal](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_33#_automatically-open-a-uri).

It would be great if we could use this same config in `tasks.json` tasks so when we say run a `npm: start` task for an express/angular/etc server a tab for it automatically opens.

title: Improve usability of minimized/maximized editors
body:
I tried as best I could to look for duplicates, but couldn't find any. For the longest time, when using cmd+X to set focus to a different editor group, only the focus (i.e. I-bar) would change to the last active editor in that group. Now, that still happens, but the editor group also gets maximized, and all my other groups minimized -- _mega annoying_ for me! I don't want my editor layout to change; I still need to able to read stuff in other groups, and with all other groups minimized, that's not possible. I also don't want to spend my time resizing all my groups with the mouse (I haven't found any key sequence to revert back to non-maximized layout, not that it would solve my issue anyway).

How do I now set focus to another editor group with the keyboard __without__ my workbench layout being altered? I've searched settings for things like "maximize", "minimize", "resize", nothing seems applicable except `"workbench.editor.centeredLayoutAutoResize"` but only kind of, and setting this to `false` (from default `true`) didn't fix the issue.

- VSCode Version: 1.33.0 (1.33.0)
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press cmd+1 or cmd+2 or cmd+3 with a 3x2 grid.

Interestingly, the issue only occurs with cmd+2 and on. cmd+1 just sets the focus. Yet all sequences of cmd+N are tied to the same behavior: "set focus to editor group N"

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: __Yes__

title: fix #23627 (proper default value in extension settings contribution)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: ![Screenshot of the extension contribution page with the issue fixed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23744935/56166619-6a259a00-5fd6-11e9-8e05-bab6735ce965.png)

title: [Feature] New extension ideas (curated by users)
body: VS Code should implement a built-in feature where we could request ideas for new extensions... that way, while you code and come up with some concept that would make coding more productive (best ideas always arise while doing), you can post it to the public wish-list, which is available for curating for other VS Code users... Top voted extension ideas each week or so gets on top and might be an awesome source of inspiration for aspiring developers looking to contribute...

title: Right-click context menu from icon in macOS dock shows different recently opened files/folders from File->Open Recent
body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.33.0
- OS Version:macOs mojave 10.14.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Launch VS Code, then choose a folder to open
2.Close the app
3.Right-click on dock icon; more than likely this folder will not be available as a shortcut (nor will it appear if click "Show Recents")

I would expect that the most-recently used files and folders would appear in this context menu as they appear in the File->Open Recent menu

Reproduces without extensions: N/A

![download](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10768018/56114171-b1cc0780-5f7d-11e9-8462-66d333b95f5d.png)

Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.
